abstract: Federal regulators said Tuesday they expected bank failures to cost the deposit insurance fund about $100 billion in the next four years, much higher than the earlier estimate of $70 billion in failure costs through 2013.
snippet: Federal regulators said Tuesday they expected bank failures to cost the deposit insurance fund about $100 billion in the next four years, much higher than the earlier estimate of $70 billion in failure costs through 2013.
lead_paragraph: Update | 12:50 p.m. Confirming previous reports, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation released a proposal Tuesday to raise $45 billion for its deposit insurance fund by having banks prepay their annual assessments. Here’s the story in The New York Times.

headline.main: F.D.I.C. Says Bank Failures Will Cost $100 Billion
